author: sky.cactus
content: The client devs are definitely working hard to mitigate every denial of service vector they find.  This is a very hard problem on a censorship resistant platform, and there is rarely a simple solution.

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, I actually consider the gas limit to be a censorship resistance issue.  IMO, anyone should be able to run an Ethereum client on commodity hardware purchased for regular usage (not specialized for running Ethereum).

author: sky.cactus
content: You should be able to go to best buy, buy a laptop for day-to-day tasks and light gaming, get a normal internet connection for watching Netflix or whatever, and be able to run Ethereum in the background.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is very much not the case right now, and largely because of the state growth problem which is a function of the gas limit.

author: bculberson
content: With the transaction rates needed for the entire network it will not be possible for any 1 client to process all transactions in the fullness of time. It may be viable to run a shard if it's small enough.

author: bculberson
content: but to expect a raspberry pi to process 1/64th the network transactions may be over limiting

author: sky.cactus
content: We definitely want to scale Ethereum to support higher throughput.  Layer 2 and sharding both help achieve this.  There is also the research work on the Portal Network, State Expiry, and Regenesis to help mitigate the long term storage requirements of layer 1.

author: sky.cactus
content: None of those are available yet though, and I'm against the high operating requirements until they become available.

author: sky.cactus
content: Aside from Proof of Stake, pretty much all major research projects in Ethereum are related to scaling.  There is a *lot* of effort being devoted to solving this problem, but it is a *really hard problem*.

author: bculberson
content: I don't know many laptops and desktops at best buy with 1tb of disk space, so I think that goal is lost for now. That could be pursued after regenesis

author: bculberson
content: Sharding would be a good time to drop the gas limits back to a much smaller size

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, we very much are not hitting that target.  The further we are from that target, the fewer end-users there are who are running an Ethereum client.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO, we should not be making the situation worse than it already is, and high gas limits only amplify the problem, while low gas limits mitigate the problem.

author: bculberson
content: Guess that's a new opinion, gas limits have increased 2x this year.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not a new opinion, just not one shared by everyone (and not miners).

author: bculberson
content: I would think miners would want the smallest gas limit possible after 1559 as they could push the network into bidding wars after the blocks were full

author: sky.cactus
content: That is unlikely to occur.

author: sky.cactus
content: They are more likely to make money (short term) by having a higher gas limit because there are more transactions.  The base fee will adjust up if the gas limit decreases, so miners won't get more.

author: bculberson
content: Good point, they actually want a volatile market. (nfts are perfect)

author: gwintery
content: actually looking at that chart, the mean price seems to be the same. What disappeared is the low spikes

author: sky.cactus
content: In my experience that is the thing people are often frustrated with.  They used to benefit from the market inefficiencies of pre-London which resulted in occasional really low dips.  I *believe* this happened because the mempool cleared out after a medium length spike in demand, and then after the demand suddenly dropped gas prices went way down.

author: sky.cactus
content: My *suspicion* is that the block elasticity makes it so we no longer experience this same behavior of mempool clearing as people are better able to express their price preferences, so we no longer see the super low drops in gas price.

author: gwintery
content: I definitely understand this frustration, and the data backs it up

author: sky.cactus
content: However, that could all be bogus and in reality what we are seeing in those lows is just miners including things that don't make financial sense (like when they do their payouts with 1 nanoeth gas price).

author: gwintery
content: fair point, i didnt think of that

content: I haven't heard of it discussed much.  I personally don't think it is necessary, but I understand the theory behind why someone might want it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Right now you cannot really express time preference strongly without resorting to a traditional gas price auction.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would be nice if you could express something like "I want this to be included within the next five minutes, but I am otherwise not in a big hurry" vs "this needs to go in right now".

author: barnabemonnot
content:
linking to a simulation we did on 1559 + escalator. it shows pretty clearly that once again the 1559 component of fees adjusting to price out most of the demand eventually dominate, so should the escalator be useful, it would really only be in these times of demand changes, and even then it might be hard to parameterise properly: https://ethereum.github.io/abm1559/notebooks/floatingEscalator.html

not claiming this settles the question, the simulation was more exploratory in nature, but I don't personally see it being implemented in protocol anytime soon
